column1: Overall, education funding is higher now than it was 20 years ago. Since 2009, however, it has declined on average, with Washington, DC, and Wyoming experiencing the most growth and Florida remaining basically flat.
column2: Overall, education funding is higher now than it was 20 years ago. Since 2009, however, it has declined on average, with Washington, DC, and Wyoming experiencing the most growth and Florida remaining basically flat.
column3: Nationwide, the combination of state and local funding increased, on average, between 1995 and 2015. Local funding typically comes from property taxes, and state funding comes from the state's general fund.
column4: Nationwide, the combination of state and local funding increased, on average, between 1995 and 2015. Local funding typically comes from property taxes, and state funding comes from the state's general fund.
column5: Because federal funding accounts for less than 10 percent of school funding, the trend lines here more or less mirror the trends in local funding alone.
column6: Because federal funding accounts for less than 10 percent of school funding, the trend lines here more or less mirror the trends in local funding alone.
column7: Because federal funding accounts for less than 10 percent of school funding and affects most states in similar ways, the trend lines here more or less mirror the trends in state funding alone. State funding comes from the general fund and is distributed through formulas that vary by state. Federal funding comes to states primarily through programs designed to reach low-income students or students with disabilities.
column8: Because federal funding accounts for less than 10 percent of school funding and affects most states in similar ways, the trend lines here more or less mirror the trends in state funding alone. State funding comes from the general fund and is distributed through formulas that vary by state. Federal funding comes to states primarily through programs designed to reach low-income students or students with disabilities.
column9: Federal funding accounts for less than 10 percent of all school funding. The largest federal funding programs are Title I, which directs money to low-income students, and child nutrition programs. The federal government also provides money to districts that serve students with disabilities, offer bilingual education programs, or are located on Indian lands. Federal funding spiked in 2010 with the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (commonly known as the stimulus).
column10: Federal funding accounts for less than 10 percent of all school funding. The largest federal funding programs are Title I, which directs money to low-income students, and child nutrition programs. The federal government also provides money to districts that serve students with disabilities, offer bilingual education programs, or are located on Indian lands. Federal funding spiked in 2010 with the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (commonly known as the stimulus).
column11: At the local level, education funding comes largely from property taxes. Most states experienced a gradual increase in local funding, though in some cases policy changes caused local funding levels to drop. Many states also experienced declines in local funding as property values fell during the Great Recession.
column12: At the local level, education funding comes largely from property taxes. Most states experienced a gradual increase in local funding, though in some cases policy changes caused local funding levels to drop. Many states also experienced declines in local funding as property values fell during the Great Recession.
column13: State funding comes from each state's general fund. Nationwide, state funding has increased 34 percent over the past 20 years, but those changes have been uneven. Vermont's funding, for example, increased 402 percent because of a change to state law, while Florida's state education funding declined.
column14: State funding comes from each state's general fund. Nationwide, state funding has increased 36 percent over the past 20 years, but those changes have been uneven. Vermont's funding, for example, increased 444 percent because of a change to state law, while Florida's state education funding declined.
column15: Overall, school district funding is about as progressive today, on average, as it was in 1995. Since then, six states increased in progressivity at least 5 percentage points, while only two states became regressive.
column16: Overall, school district funding is about as progressive today, on average, as it was in 1995. Since then, six states increased in progressivity at least 5 percentage points, while only two states became regressive.
column17: State funding formulas are generally designed to balance out regressive local funding formulas. Local funding comes largely from property taxes, and state funding typically comes from sales and income taxes. States vary in the degree to which the progressivity of state funding balances out regressive local funding.
column18: State funding formulas are generally designed to balance out regressive local funding formulas. Local funding comes largely from property taxes, and state funding typically comes from sales and income taxes. States vary in the degree to which the progressivity of state funding balances out regressive local funding.
column19: Looking at the combination of local and federal funding doesn't reveal much, because state funding is typically designed to fill in the gaps local funding creates.
column20: Looking at the combination of local and federal funding doesn't reveal much, because state funding is typically designed to fill in the gaps local funding creates.
column21: The combination of state and federal funding is generally progressive. Almost all state funding formulas attempt to divide funding in a progressive way, and federal funding is progressive by design, with the largest federal funding programs, Title I and child nutrition programs, directing money to districts serving low-income students.
column22: The combination of state and federal funding is generally progressive. Almost all state funding formulas attempt to divide funding in a progressive way, and federal funding is progressive by design, with the largest federal funding programs, Title I and child nutrition programs, directing money to districts serving low-income students.
column23: Federal funding accounts for less than 10 percent of all school funding. Federal funding is progressive by design, with the largest federal funding programs, Title I and child nutrition programs, directing money to districts serving low-income students. The federal government also provides money to districts that serve students with disabilities, offer bilingual education programs, or are located on Indian lands.
column24: Federal funding accounts for less than 10 percent of all school funding. Federal funding is progressive by design, with the largest federal funding programs, Title I and child nutrition programs, directing money to districts serving low-income students. The federal government also provides money to districts that serve students with disabilities, offer bilingual education programs, or are located on Indian lands.
column25: At the local level, education funding comes largely from property taxes. We expect local funding to be regressive, given that districts with more poor families tend to have fewer local dollars coming in, and therefore less money to spend, than districts with fewer poor students.
column26: At the local level, education funding comes largely from property taxes. We expect local funding to be regressive, given that districts with more poor families tend to have fewer local dollars coming in, and therefore less money to spend, than districts with fewer poor students.
column27: Each state has its own funding formula to distribute money, but almost all attempt to divide funding in a progressive way. Whether they succeed in doing so depends on the specifics of the formula and on how districts are divided. In states with large, countywide districts, for example, it is difficult to target districts serving low-income students.
column28: Each state has its own funding formula to distribute money, but almost all attempt to divide funding in a progressive way. Whether they succeed in doing so depends on the specifics of the formula and on how districts are divided. In states with large, homogenous districts, for example, it is difficult to target districts serving low-income students.
